questions.text: A patient has developed confusion and keeps bumping into objects. He can speak fluently. But on examination, he cannot differentiate between fingers and cannot write. He also gets confused with the examiner's right and left sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule.

Gerstmann syndrome consists of:

  • Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic
  • Dysgraphia - impaired writing
  • Finger anomia - an inability to name individual fingers 
  • Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body

Option B: Anton syndrome also known as visual anosognosia occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs. It produces cortical blindness and the patients are unaware of the blindness or may even deny it.

Option C: Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. It causes functional loss of the 6th and 7th cranial nerves and corticospinal tract. This presents as diplopia, ipsilateral facial palsy, ipsilateral loss of corneal reflex, contralateral hemiparesis.

Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

Disease

Site of lesion

Clinical features

Anton’s syndrome

B/L infarction in the distal PCAs

Cortical blindness, with denial or unawareness of blindness

Balint’s syndrome

Low flow in the “watershed region” between distal PCA and MCA territories

Palinopsia

Asimultanagnosia

Optic ataxia

Ocular apraxia

 

Weber’s syndrome

Midbrain

I/L CN III palsy

C/L hemiplegia

Parinaud’s syndrome

Dorsal midbrain

Tetrad of symptoms:

Loss of upgaze

Light-near dissociation

Convergence – retraction nystagmus

Lid retraction

Benedikt syndrome

Midbrain

Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy

Contralateral hemiparesis

Contralateral cerebellar ataxia

Holmes tremor

Choreoathetosis

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with right hemisensory loss followed by agonizing, burning pain in the affected regions. The pain responds poorly to analgesics. These features are classically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions is classically seen in Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

Dejerine- Roussy syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches arising from the P1 segment resulting in contralateral hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions.

The P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery extends from the basilar bifurcation to the junction with the posterior communicating artery.

This pain responds poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman was brought to the OPD since she has been tripping over things at home. On entering, she complimented the doctor’s tie even though he was not wearing one and continued to insist that she could see normally. On examination, bilateral blindness was present but pupillary light reflex was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Anton's syndrome. It occurs due to bilateral infarction in the distal posterior cerebral artery (P2 segment) and is associated with the following features:

  • Cortical blindness with preserved pupillary light reaction
  • Visual anosognosia - denial of loss of vision
  • Confabulation in the setting of obvious visual loss

Option D: Riddoch phenomenon is a condition where cortical blindness is associated with the perception of only moving targets.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

questions.text: A patient with a history of ischemic heart disease now comes to the hospital due to problems with vision. She complains that while turning her head, the image of the previous target still persists for a few seconds before she can see the new target. This phenomenon is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The persistence of visual image even after shifting gaze is called palinopsia. It is seen in Balint’s syndrome.

Balint’s syndrome results due to low flow in the watershed areas between distal PCA and MCA territories. It is characterized by the following:

  • Palinopsia - persistence of a visual image despite gazing at another scene
  • Asimultagnosia - difficulty to focus on more than one item in the visual field
  • Optic ataxia - Inability to reach accurately under visual guidance
  • Ocular apraxia - Inability to direct gaze accurately to a new target

Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. It is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain.

Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following features do you not expect to see in a patient with Balint's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Opsoclonus is not seen in Balint's syndrome.

The features of Balint’s syndrome are:

  • Optic ataxia - the inability to guide the arm to reach a certain object in the visual field
  • Simultanagnosia - the inability to perceive more than one object at a time. In other words, it is the inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole.
  • Ocular apraxia - the inability to control voluntary purposeful eye movements
  • Palinopsia - the persistence of a visual image even after the stimulus has been removed

Note: While some authors use the term simultanagnosia, others use asimultanagnosia instead. A few authors also use these two terminologies interchangeably.

questions.text: A patient presents with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is seen in Weber’s syndrome.

Weber’s syndrome occurs due to infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the PCA. It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, and damages III cranial nerve and the pyramidal fibers. It results in contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy.

Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third cranial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. This is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral paralysis of the lower face is not seen in Weber's syndrome. However, there is contralateral paralysis of the lower face.

Weber syndrome is caused by infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA). It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, with damage to the fascicle of cranial nerve III and the pyramidal fibers.

The resultant clinical findings are contralateral hemiplegia of the face, arm, and leg secondary to corticospinal and corticobulbar tract involvement, and ipsilateral oculomotor paresis including a dilated pupil.

 

Structure damaged

Effect

Cranial nerve III fibres
  • Ipsilateral ptosis
  • Ipsilateral divergent squint
  • Loss of accommodation reflex
  • Loss of light reflex

Corticobulbar tract

UMN lesion leading to contralateral paralysis of the lower face

Corticospinal tract

Contralateral hemiplegia

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of upgaze and convergence-retraction nystagmus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of convergence-retraction nystagmus and loss of upgaze is seen in Parinaud's syndrome. It is caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain.

The following tetrad of symptoms are seen:

  1. Loss of upgaze
  2. Light-near dissociation
  3. Convergence-retraction nystagmus
  4. Lid retraction

Convergence‐retraction nystagmus is irregular, jerky nystagmus in which both eyeballs rhythmically converge and retract into the orbit, particularly on attempting an upward gaze.

Nothnagel syndrome is associated with oculomotor palsy and contralateral limb ataxia. Underlying structures involved are the superior cerebellar peduncle and tectum of the midbrain.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

questions.text: A patient presented with left-sided hemiplegia and examination revealed right-sided abducens nerve palsy and facial nerve palsy. Further investigation revealed a right-sided pontine haemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral abducens and facial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia are seen in Millard–Gubler syndrome.

In this syndrome, there is a ventral pontine injury (lesion in abducens fascicle) that causes lateral rectus palsy.

CNS lesion  

  Effects

Millard–Gubler Syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve weakness
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Raymond’s Syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Foville’s Syndrome

 
  • Lateral gaze palsy
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Balint's syndrome
  • Optic ataxia
  • Ocular apraxia
  • Visuospatial disorientation

Lateral pontine syndrome (Marie-Foix syndrome)
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Contralateral loss of proprioception & vibration
  • Ipsilateral limb ataxia
  • Ipsilateral facial palsy
  • Lateral hearing loss
  • Vertigo
  • Nystagmus

questions.text: Which of the following differentiates Foville’s syndrome from Millard-Gubler syndrome?
questions.solution:
Lateral gaze palsy is a feature of Foville’s Syndrome which is a result of dorsal pontine injury.

Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to ventral pontine injury. Lateral gaze palsy does not occur in this condition because the abducens fascicle is injured rather than the nucleus.

CNS lesion  

  Effects

Millard–Gubler Syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve weakness
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Raymond’s Syndrome
  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Foville’s Syndrome

 
  • Lateral gaze palsy
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy
  • Contralateral hemiplegia

Balint's syndrome
  • Optic ataxia
  • Ocular apraxia
  • Visuospatial disorientation

Lateral pontine syndrome (Marie-Foix syndrome)
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Contralateral loss of proprioception & vibration
  • Ipsilateral limb ataxia
  • Ipsilateral facial palsy
  • Lateral hearing loss
  • Vertigo
  • Nystagmus
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes _______.
questions.solution:
Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) causes lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome.

PICA is a branch of the fourth part of the vertebral artery, which is a branch of the first part of subclavian artery. 

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Wallenberg syndrome is most commonly caused by thrombosis of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Thrombosis of the vertebral artery is most commonly implicated in Wallenberg syndrome.

Wallenberg syndrome, also called lateral medullary syndrome, is due to occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery in most cases. In the remainder, posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible.

Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of cranial nerve V - Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves - Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of tractus solitarius - Ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract - Ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract - Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract - Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the body.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following features do you not expect to see in a patient with Wallenberg syndrome?

choices.text: Impaired sensation on ipsilateral half of face

questions.solution:
The pyramidal tracts are not affected in Wallenberg syndrome and therefore hemiplegia is not seen.

Wallenberg / lateral medullary syndrome affects the following structures:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V - I/L impaired sensation over half of face
  • IX and X CN - I/L paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius – I/L loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract – I/L ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract – I/L Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – C/L impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of the body.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face

  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with medial medullary syndrome?
questions.solution:
Horner’s syndrome is not a feature of medial medullary syndrome.  

Medial medullary syndrome occurs due to the occlusion of the vertebral artery or a branch of the vertebral or basilar artery. The features of medial medullary syndrome are

  • CN XII - Ipsilateral paralysis of the tongue
  • Pyramidal tract - Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Medial lemniscus - Impaired tactile and proprioception over the contralateral half of the body

Horner’s syndrome occurs due to a lesion involving the sympathetic fibres. It is seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.text: Which is the most common site of bleed in patients with intracerebral hypertensive haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The most common site for intracerebral hypertensive hemorrhage is the putamen.

The most common type of intracranial haemorrhage is an intraparenchymal i.e., intracerebral haemorrhage. It is most often caused by a hypertensive bleed.

Most common sites of intracerebral hypertensive bleed:

  • Putamen (basal ganglia)
  • Thalamus
  • Cerebellum
  • Pons.

questions.text: Raised intracranial tension is not associated with which of the following manifestations?
questions.solution:
Raised ICT is not associated with paraparesis.

Manifestations of raised ICT include:

  • Hypertension
  • Bradycardia
  • Respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy
  • Seizures

Paraparesis is usually caused by a spinal lesion such as thoracic myelopathy and neoplasms causing compression of the spinal cord.   

Rare intracranial causes of paraparesis are:

  • Parasagittal meningioma
  • Occlusion of unpaired anterior cerebral artery
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis affecting the sagittal sinus.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of Cushing’s triad?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia is a component of Cushing's triad.

Cushing’s triad is characteristically seen in raised ICT. Its components are as follows:

  • Hypertension
  • Bradycardia
  • Respiratory depression.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. There is no history of trauma. CT head is shown below. What is the most common cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of non-traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage. The most common cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm, also known as a saccular aneurysm.

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

Most unruptured intracranial aneurysms are completely asymptomatic. Prodromal symptoms occasionally suggest the site of the enlarging unruptured aneurysm. For example, cranial nerve III palsy with loss of ipsilateral light reflex and focal pain above or behind the eye suggests an expanding aneurysm at the junction of the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid artery.

Ruptured aneurysms cause an excruciating thunderclap headache followed by a transient loss of consciousness.

Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for SAH. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF.

Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most likely to be compressed by an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery?
questions.solution:
Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery will most likely compress the oculomotor nerve. This is because the posterior communicating artery is anatomically located very close to the oculomotor nerve.

Patients with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can present with symptoms of oculomotor nerve palsy such as:

  • Unilateral ptosis (LPS)
  • Outward eye deviation (MR)
  • Dilated pupil.

The nerves controlling the pupils are located very superficially and these are always affected due to the mass effect of the aneurysm. Therefore the pupil sparing third nerve palsies are unlikely to be due to an aneurysm. 

Pupil-sparing oculomotor nerve palsy is often assumed to be caused by ischemic injuries such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

Expanding unruptured aneurysms can occasionally lead to prodromal symptoms which suggest the location of the aneurysm.

questions.text: At which of the following locations does a Berry aneurysm have the highest risk of rupture?
questions.solution:
The size and site of aneurysm are important in predicting the risk of rupture. Aneurysms with the following features have a greater risk of rupture:

  • Size >7 mm in diameter 
  • Located at the top of the basilar artery (i.e origin of the posterior cerebral artery)
  • Located near the origin of the posterior communicating artery.

The most common location of Berry aneurysm is the anterior communicating artery.

questions.text: The CT finding of a patient is shown below. What is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a subdural hematoma and it most commonly results from injury to the bridging dural veins. 

Subdural hematoma refers to the haemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater. The image of the CT scan reveals a hyperdense crescentic lesion. Mass effect with midline displacement can also be seen.

Causes of SDH are:

  • Trauma
  • Anticoagulants
  • Antiplatelets
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Shaken baby syndrome.

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhage are:

  • Typically unilateral
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain
  • Not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections
  • Chronic subdural hemorrhage: Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT
  • Acute subdural hemorrhage: Hyperdense collections on CT

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: The CT scan of a patient who was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident is shown below. Between what structures does blood accumulate in this condition?

choices.text: Outer table and inner table of the skull
Periosteum and aponeurotic layer of scalp

questions.solution:
The given CT image is suggestive of extradural haemorrhage (EDH). In this condition, blood accumulates between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater.

The typical presentation is an initial loss of consciousness following trauma, a complete transient recovery (lucid interval), and a rapid progression of neurological deterioration.

This condition is treated by rapid surgical evacuation and ligation or cautery of the damaged vessel.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery

  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)

  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding extradural hemorrhage?

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery bleed is the most common source

questions.solution:
In extradural hemorrhage (EDH), CT brain does not show a crescentric opacity. It shows a lentiform opacity.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive man presented with an acute-onset headache for the past 2 hours, neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting. He claims it is the worst headache of his life. There are no focal neurological deficits and his CT scan shows blood in the Sylvian fissure. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of sudden-onset headache with neck stiffness, nausea, and vomiting with no neurological deficits is suggestive of a diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage. The presence of blood in the Sylvian fissure confirms this diagnosis.

Trauma is the most common cause. However, spontaneous sub-arachnoid bleeding occurs most often due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm. Most of them are found in the anterior circulation, mostly on the circle of Willis. The three most common locations are:

  • Terminal ICA
  • MCA bifurcation
  • Top of the basilar artery.

A non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice. LP shows xanthochromatic CSF.

Treatment involves clipping or coiling the aneurysm to eliminate the risk of rebleeding.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.

Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. 

Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum. 

Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration ≤ 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving ≥ one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours ≥ 80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.

World Stroke Day is on October 29 every year. On this day, people everywhere share important information about recognizing the signs of a stroke, how to stay healthy, and ways to prevent strokes. The theme this year, as designated by WSO, is ‘Together we are #Greater Than Stroke.’ In India, the average stroke incidence rate is 145 per 1,00,000 population.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.
